Posts.Content: By Radha_Inspire Digital Editor, Inspire Laura Pole, RN, MSN, is the Director of Nourishment Programs at the Smith Center for Healing and the Arts in Washington, D.C., a non-profit health, education, and arts organization, and senior researcher for Beyond Conventional Cancer Therapies, an open access, evidence-based resource for those interested in integrative cancer care. Pole trained and practiced as an oncology nurse before pursuing an interest in the science of food and nutrition to support cancer patients. We spoke with Pole about her work as a health-supportive chef. How would you describe what you do? I am a culinary translator. If someone has been told “this is the diet you need to eat”, or they’ve done their research and decided [how they] want to eat, I help them translate it in all the practical ways to get it to their plate and it tastes good. Whether it’s teaching them to cook or shop or plan menus, working with someone else who’s going to cook for them, or teaching them how to go out and eat if they aren’t up for cooking. Nourishment is everything about food, from selecting and preparing it, to enjoying it, to digesting it, to it working with your body to take care of you. At what point do people come to you to address diet as part of cancer care? Sometimes we’ll have people who from the get-go know they want to take an integrative approach to their care and they’ll ask for help. But in the shock of a diagnosis and trying to do everything you can to figure out your treatment and get through it, we don’t see too many seriously looking at diet until after [that]. I mostly get people who are done with treatment and now they want to know what they can do related to eating that will reduce the risk of recurrence. I like to help people understand [how to use] food and other healing practices to make the body inhospitable to cancer. The kind of eating pattern we’re talking about is a primarily plant-based, whole foods diet – like eating apples with the skin vs drinking apple juice. How can food make the body inhospitable to cancer? We’re now pretty sure that obesity is connected to at least 13 different cancers – it’s getting as clear as smoking is clear[ly] related to cancer. The fat that accumulates is active, causing inflammation and interfering with the insulin system. Insulin resistance, which a lot of people with obesity have – but you can have it even if you’re not obese – happens when you eat high glycemic load foods (refined flours, white pasta, white bread). Consider insulin like a real estate agent taking glucose into [cellular] homes… When you have more glucose than cells want to take up, cells become resistant to the insulin – that’s insulin resistance – yet the pancreas is still kicking out insulin. Cancer cells will take the glucose, and the insulin says, “I’ll give you some growth factor while we’re at it.” That’s the last thing you want! What questions could patients and caregivers ask of their primary caregivers or oncologists in order to get them to a nutrition-related resource? They could say something like: “I feel like food and diet is going to be important to my healing. I plan to look into that. I wonder what your thoughts are on it?” Whether your doctor knows about what you’re exploring, it’s important to let them know that you’re doing it or you’re thinking about it so they can flag concerns. There are a lot of sources and videos on the Internet that are out of date. You need to look for reliable sources. A lot of people don’t know about the culinary translation piece. You can ask for a referral to an oncology dietician. There are doctors who practice integrative or more holistic medicine and we talk about how to find them [at the Smith Center]. You might want to work with a navigator who’s trained in understanding integrative cancer care. There are a subgroup of naturopaths called naturopathic oncologists. If they are true to their profession, they will work cooperatively with your conventional medicine doctors… to help people with lifestyle practices, maybe supplements, complementary therapies, natural approaches, that will complement your conventional cancer treatment. How can eating well for cancer accommodate different cultures and food traditions? One thing you do is you go back to the roots of the food for that culture... what were the traditional foods? If you look at Latin American cuisine, if you look at African cuisine, there’s a lot of health supportive foods in it. If you think about the Mediterranean diet, [which is] based on the cultures and ethnicities of the people who live on the Mediterranean, that’s one of the most evidence-based diets for good health outcomes, including for cancer, heart disease, cardiovascular disease. I like [the writer] Michael Pollan’s advice – eat real food, not too much, mostly plants. Is there anything else important to mention? I was getting to the end of a lecture when I talk about “delicious” being a very important principle. [A French student] couldn’t contain herself and she said: “You keep talking about the science but in my country, we love food, we enjoy it, it’s pleasure! And that has to be good for you.” I said you’re right and maybe I should talk about that first. [Food] doesn’t have to be like taking a bad medicine and it doesn’t have to be complicated. And pleasure should be part of it. What resources help you stay updated on the latest thinking about cancer and diet? The American Institute for Cancer Research’s Continuous Update Project (CUP) reports review literature for several cancers. I listen to [Five to Thrive Live!] on iThrive Radio where they interview an expert in some topic related to cancer, quite often related to diet. The Center for Mind-Body Medicine does trainings twice a year on food as medicine, and I have done that training and was on the faculty for some time.
